item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Well, it’s simple then: Use microsoft visual c++ if your on Windows, and use GCC if your on UNIX.

Or you can get the Intel compilers if your on an x86/x64 platform and actually have fast programs

item.title: C++ Opener
item.dc:creator: @Rune_Hacker1 Rune Hacker
item.description:
@Rune_Hacker1 wrote:

Javacisnotrecognized:

Because Windows and Unix have different extensions to the C standard, and different compilers implement different extensions. And stop calling them scripts, dumbass.

No need to call me a dumbass because i said the word “script” once…And lets say i went to a source code sight, how would i run those? Would i need all the C++ compilers downloaded and try them one at a time until i fidn the one that works or what??? It would be really stupid if that was how it’s done lol.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ Opener
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Because Windows and Unix have different extensions to the C standard, and different compilers implement different extensions. And stop calling them scripts, dumbass.

About this:if (pass = '123') variable length characters might have different values on large and small endian machines, and even from compiler to compiler. You shouldn’t use those.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ Opener
item.dc:creator: @Rune_Hacker1 Rune Hacker
item.description:
@Rune_Hacker1 wrote:

I don’t get why there are so many compilers for C++. All the source code sites never freakin work for me and its annoying. I currently use Dev-C++ and i have Microsoft Visual C++ but I have no idea how to get it to work. Is it just me or does a script only work with the same compiler it was made in? Why are all C++ compilers so freakin different?

Read full topic

item.title: C++ Opener
item.dc:creator: @Baros_Rocks Baros Rocks
item.description:
@Baros_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“Exception, post:6, topic:141290”][quote author=reece844 link=topic=193505.msg1741055#msg1741055 date=1189291652]

if (pass = '123')

I don’t think you compiled this, as in that code, you are assigning pass the value 123 in a if statement. Not gunna wurk.
Besides that, you could have at least have it MD5 hash the inputted password and compare it -.-

Too bad it does work. did you compile it?
[/quote]
Did YOU compile it, because it DOESN’T work.
GCC tells me…

38:28 C:\Dev-Cpp\Untitled1.cpp [Warning] multi-character character constant

And guess what line 38 is?

if (pass = '123') [/quote]

You can still run it.

Read full topic
